assessments.task_description:
There will be 4 multi-choice exercises based on the set readings, run through Blackboard. Each exercise is worth 5 marks, for a total of 20 marks. Students are asked not to collaborate on the exercises and to submit their own work. All of the exercises will be available to complete from Week 1, but must be completed by the set deadline.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
During the Week 7 seminar, the following in-person exam will be conducted using strict examination procedures. As this is an internal course, a student must make themself available to undertake their examination at the scheduled date, time, and venue. Please see Exam Procedures for full information. Mobile phones, ipads, apple watches and other electronic devices must be turned off or in airplane mode and placed on the floor under a student's desk. Where a devise emits any noise, the student may be subject to allegations of misconduct and the items may be confiscated for the duration of the examination.

The exam - Teachers Notes

Working from Shauna's Great Expectations by Kathleen Loughnan, write a section or sections that might be included in a set of teachers' notes. You must include at least one writing exercise based on the novel for students to attempt. The audience for the notes is students (not teachers, although teachers might use the notes to help with learning outcomes in the classroom).

Aim to produce material that shows deep insight into this novel, and then provokes discussion and debate among students about the themes and characterisations that the author has used throughout the work. Exemplar Teachers' Notes written by industry professionals are provided to help you plan (in advance) for this in-class exam.

Format

90 minute written exam. Teacher's Notes should be handwritten during the Week 7 Seminar. This is an in-person test.

Wordcount: 800 - 1000 words (about 3 -7 handwritten pages). You may use dot points where appropriate for lists.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit written exam paper directly to your instructor at the end of the exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Your writing portfolio will include a query letter to a publisher incorporating a synopsis and a 2200-2400 word writing sample. There is a pass/fail viva for this assignment.

The Query Letter (600 words max total)

The letter should include a compelling intro which includes the novel's word count, comparative titles and genre, an appropriate synopsis (about 300 words), a brief author bio, and a professional closing. This submission is the result of workshopping with your peers in-person/remotely.

The Writing Sample (2200-2400 range)

Include the opening of a Middle Grade or Young Adult novel, in the genre of the student's choice. This submission is the result of workshopping with your peers in seminars/remotely.

Total combined PORTFOLIO wordcount: approx 3000 words. Do not go under 2700 words or over 3000 words.

If a submission exceeds the specified word range, the content of the submission must be assessed and the element of non-compliance marked through a separate criterion, and/or the assessment marked up to the specified word limit.

Format

12pt Times New Roman, double-spaced, first line of each section set left, subsequent paragraph first lines are inset. Student name, student number and page number in the footer. Wordcounts, title of novel, AI statement on a front page.


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
5 minute Viva:

Your Writing Portfolio is worth 50% of the course. It includes a 5-minute verbal exam (viva) to discuss your work in week 13 which is a pass/fail hurdle. This means that if you are unable to demonstrate your research and writing process, idea formation, challenges faced and addressed during the creation of your final Writing Portfolio, you will fail the Writing Portfolio assessment (50%).

All Vivas will be recorded. Recordings will be retained by the School of Communication and Arts for at least 12 months from the release of the final grade for the course.  

Recordings will be stored in a secure manner and will only be accessed by authorised school staff for the purposes of: 

  • Moderation of marking;  
  • Provision of feedback to the student(s) recorded; and/or  
  • Re-marking following a successful re-mark application. 


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
